question.text:
How many of the following statements are true in the context of the salient features human genome project?

I. There are 1.4 million SNPs.
II. 99.9% genome is similar in all humans.
III. 32% of genome codes for proteins.
IV. The largest human gene is dystrophin with 2.4 million base pairs.
V. The human genome has a maximum number of genes on 1st chromosome i.e., 3968.

solution.text:
Some characteristics of the Human Genome:

- There are 3164.7 million nucleotide bases in Human genome

- The number of genes in Human genome is about 30,000.

- Average gene consists of 3000 bases, but sizes vary. The largest gene in human is dystrophin found on X-chromosome that has 2.4 million bases. Although, average gene in human has 3000 bases but varies in size.

- Out of all the nucleotide bases 99.9% are identical and only 0.1% is different which makes each of us unique.

- Functions of over 50 of discovered genes are unknown.

- Most genes are found in Chromosome I  ~2968 and Y has the fewest 231.

- Less than 2% of the genome codes for proteins.

- Repeated sequences make up very large portion of human genome.

- Approximately 1.4 million SNPs (SNPs- Single nucleotide polymorphism or 'snips') are found in human genome.
